title: How to Make Blackberry Syrup

steps.headline: Put the berries, sugar, and water into a saucepan.
steps.description: Set a medium saucepan on the stove and put 1 pound (450 g) of fresh or thawed blackberries into it along with 6 tablespoons (75 g) of granulated sugar, and ⁄4 cup (59 ml) of water.Tip: To thaw frozen blackberries, defrost them in the microwave in 30-second increments or place the berries in the refrigerator overnight.

steps.headline: Stir in the juice of 1 lemon if you want a slight citrus flavor.
steps.description: To cut some of the sweetness of the syrup, add the juice from 1 lemon. Use fresh lemon juice for the brightest flavor. For extra-citrus flavor, you can also zest the lemon and add it to the saucepan.

steps.headline: Bring the mixture to a boil over medium-high heat.
steps.description: Stir the berries occasionally as they cook and release liquid. The sugar should dissolve once the blackberry mixture begins to boil. Don't worry if the berries begin to fall apart or bruise since you'll be blending them anyway.

steps.headline: Simmer the berry mixture over low heat for 20 to 30 minutes.
steps.description: Turn the burner down to low heat so the liquid is bubbling gently. Keep the lid off of the saucepan and cook the blackberry mixture until the berries fall apart. Turn off the burner once the syrup is as thick as you like. Stir the blackberry mixture occasionally as it simmers to prevent it from sticking to the bottom of the saucepan.

steps.headline: Strain the blackberry syrup through a fine mesh strainer.
steps.description: Put a bowl underneath a fine mesh strainer and slowly pour the blackberry syrup into the strainer. Some of the syrup will immediately drip through the strainer into the bowl. If you don't have a fine mesh strainer, place a few layers of cheesecloth into a colander and put the blackberry mixture into the cheesecloth.

steps.headline: Push the blackberry syrup through the strainer.
steps.description: Take a wooden spoon and push the back of it against the blackberry mixture. Do this gently so the syrup is forced into the bowl, but the seeds remain in the strainer. You'll probably need to do this for several minutes to extract all of the syrup. Discard the solids that are left in the fine mesh strainer.

steps.headline: Cool the blackberry syrup before using or storing it.
steps.description: Cover the bowl of blackberry syrup and refrigerate it until it's cool enough to use. If you prefer to store the syrup for longer, transfer it to an airtight container and refrigerate it for up to 2 weeks. Keep in mind that the syrup will thicken more as it's refrigerated.

steps.headline: Multiply a batch and can the syrup if you want to store it for 1 year.
steps.description: Make at least a triple batch of blackberry syrup and sterilize 2 half-pint jars. Fill the jars with the syrup and leave ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) of headspace. Process the jars for 10 minutes in a water bath and store the syrup for up to 1 year. Remember to label the jars and store them in the pantry for up to 1 year.

steps.headline: Stir a few spoonfuls of blackberry syrup into cocktails or tea.
steps.description:
Adjust how much syrup you add according to how sweet you want to make the drink. Keep in mind that the blackberry syrup will add a dark purple tint to your beverage. Try adding blackberry syrup to any of these drinks:
Margaritas
Sangria
Iced tea
Mojitos
Lemonade

steps.headline: Drizzle blackberry syrup over pancakes or waffles.
steps.description: Instead of reaching for classic pancake or maple syrup, pour a little blackberry syrup over your favorite breakfast items. Consider warming the syrup before pouring it so your waffles or pancakes stay hot. If you don't want to use straight blackberry syrup, mix a little of the blackberry syrup into maple or pancake syrup.

steps.headline: Whisk 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of syrup into a vinaigrette.
steps.description:
Simply whisk in enough blackberry syrup to add a tangy sweetness to your favorite vinaigrette. Then pour the blackberry vinaigrette over fresh greens and serve them immediately. Simple Vinaigrette
Ingredients:
3 tablespoons (44 ml) of extra-virgin olive oil

1 tablespoon (15 ml) of apple cider vinegar
Salt and pepper to tasteWhisk the ingredients until they're completely combined. You can also put the ingredients in a sealed jar and shake until they're mixed.

steps.headline: Stir blackberry syrup into yogurt, pudding, or ice cream.
steps.description: Blackberry syrup also pairs well with oatmeal, rice pudding, and egg custards. If you're serving pale foods, remember that the syrup will tint them pink. For a sophisticated topping, drizzle blackberry syrup over ice cream. Use any flavor ice cream such as vanilla, ginger, or strawberry.

steps.headline: Brush blackberry syrup over ham or roasts.
steps.description: To make an easy glaze, dip a pastry brush in the syrup and coat a spiral-cut ham or pork roast. The glaze will sweeten the meat and add a rich, dark color as the meat bakes. You can also stir blackberry syrup according to your taste into prepared barbecue sauce. This will give the sauce a slightly fruity flavor.
